title: Edward McEvoy
text:
Edward Francis McEvoy, sometimes spelled MacEvoy, (5 September 1826 – 10 February 1899) was an <a href="Irish%20people">Irish</a> <a href="Irish%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> and <a href="Independent%20Irish%20Party">Independent Irish Party</a> politician.
McEvoy was the son of James McEvoy of Tobertinan (Tobertynan House & Estate, <a href="Rathmolyon">Rathmolyon</a>, <a href="County%20Meath">County Meath</a>) and Theresa Maria Meredyth, daughter of <a href="Sir%20Joshua%20Colles%20Meredyth%2C%208th%20Baronet">Sir Joshua Colles Meredyth</a>. He joined <a href="Magdalene%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Magdalene College, Cambridge</a> in 1845. In April 1846, he joined the <a href="Carabiniers%20%286th%20Dragoon%20Guards%29">6th Dragoon Guards</a> as a cornet, and between 1847 and 1851, he was a lieutenant of the same group. He married Eliza Browne, daughter of Andrew Browne of Mount Hazel in 1850. Together they had one child: Pauline Mary McEvoy (–1944), who married the 4th Duke of Stacpoole.
At some point, he was a <a href="Justice%20of%20the%20Peace">Justice of the Peace</a>. He also received the <a href="Order%20of%20St.%20Gregory%20the%20Great">Order of St. Gregory the Great</a>.
At a <a href="1855%20Meath%20by-election">by-election in 1855</a>, McEvoystood as an Independent Irish candidate and was elected as one of the two <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Members of Parliament</a> (MPs) for <a href="Meath%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Meath</a> . He was again elected at the next <a href="1859%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">general election in 1859</a> and shortly after joined the Liberal Party on its formation. He then held the seat until <a href="1874%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">1874</a> when he stood down.
